user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_:
```c
int
MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (const char *str1,
                         const char *str2)
{
  while (0 != (*str1))
  {
    const char c1 = *str1;
    const char c2 = *str2;
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
    {
      str1++;
      str2++;
    }
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return 0 == (*str2);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
while (0 != (*str1))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17: the fragment only dereferences str1 and does not call any <string.h> function. Rule 21.17 applies specifically to standard string.h functions (e.g. memcpy, strlen, strcpy, etc.). Note: a runtime out-of-bounds/dereference can still occur if str1 is NULL or not a pointer to a valid null-terminated object, but that would violate other rules (not 21.17). A concrete 21.17 violation scenario would be calling strlen(str1) or strcpy(dst,str1) when str1 is not null-terminated, which could read beyond the bounds of the referenced object.
